root.pub-comments: This is a subtree of the deaf sign language tree provided in Ethnologue. It has been broken into regions for ease of searching.
root.publications: Gordon, Raymond G. (ed.). 2005. Ethnologue: Languages of the World, 15 edn. http://www.ethnologue.com/15/web.asp. (09 July, 2008.)

child.pub-comments: The sources from which the sign language developed were indigenous sign systems before 1895, Japanese occupation and education 1895–1946, Mainland Chinese Sign Language brought by refugees in 1949 and some from Hongkong since. Lexical similarity 50% with Japanese Sign Language. Quite different from (Mainland) Chinese Sign Language; only a few signs are the same or similar. Not related to Taiwanese languages. Some signs are borrowed from Mandarin through palmwriting. There is also a Signed Mandarin (Wenfa Shouyu).
child.publications: Gordon, Raymond G. (ed.). 2005. Ethnologue: Languages of the World, 15 edn. http://www.ethnologue.com/15/web.asp. (09 July, 2008.)
Gordon, Raymond G. (ed.). 2005. Ethnologue: Languages of the World, 15 edn. http://www.ethnologue.com/15/web.asp. (09 July, 2008.)
Gordon, Raymond G. (ed.). 2005. Ethnologue: Languages of the World, 15 edn. http://www.ethnologue.com/15/web.asp. (09 July, 2008.)
Gordon, Raymond G. (ed.). 2005. Ethnologue: Languages of the World, 15 edn. http://www.ethnologue.com/15/web.asp. (09 July, 2008.)

child.pub-comments: Developed from local signs and introduced signs. Related to Indian and Pakistan Sign Languages.
child.publications: Gordon, Raymond G. (ed.). 2005. Ethnologue: Languages of the World, 15 edn. http://www.ethnologue.com/15/web.asp. (09 July, 2008.)
Gordon, Raymond G. (ed.). 2005. Ethnologue: Languages of the World, 15 edn. http://www.ethnologue.com/15/web.asp. (09 July, 2008.)

child.pub-comments: Over 75% of signs from all regions are related. Mumbai-Delhi dialect is the most influential. Some influence from British Sign Language in the fingerspelling system and a few other signs. Developed indigenously in India. Related to Nepalese Sign Language.
child.alt-names: Indo-Pakistani Sign Language, Urban Indian Sign Language
child.publications: Gordon, Raymond G. (ed.). 2005. Ethnologue: Languages of the World, 15 edn. http://www.ethnologue.com/15/web.asp. (09 July, 2008.)
child.geography: India. Also used in Bangladesh, Pakistan.

child.publications: Gordon, Raymond G. (ed.). 2005. Ethnologue: Languages of the World, 15 edn. http://www.ethnologue.com/15/web.asp. (09 July, 2008.)
Gordon, Raymond G. (ed.). 2005. Ethnologue: Languages of the World, 15 edn. http://www.ethnologue.com/15/web.asp. (09 July, 2008.)

Gordon, Raymond G. (ed.). 2005. Ethnologue: Languages of the World, 15 edn. http://www.ethnologue.com/15/web.asp. (09 July, 2008.)

child.pub-comments: Related to sign languages in Hanoi, Haiphong, Laos, and earlier sign languages in Thailand.
child.publications: Gordon, Raymond G. (ed.). 2005. Ethnologue: Languages of the World, 15 edn. http://www.ethnologue.com/15/web.asp. (09 July, 2008.)
child.geography: Vient Nam, Ho Chi Minh City.
child.pri-name: Ho Chi Minh City Sign Language

child.pub-comments: Different from Russian Sign Language and other sign languages.
child.publications: Gordon, Raymond G. (ed.). 2005. Ethnologue: Languages of the World, 15 edn. http://www.ethnologue.com/15/web.asp. (09 July, 2008.)

child.pub-comments: Related to sign languages in Hanoi, Ho Chi Minh City, Laos, and earlier sign languages in Thailand.
child.publications: Gordon, Raymond G. (ed.). 2005. Ethnologue: Languages of the World, 15 edn. http://www.ethnologue.com/15/web.asp. (09 July, 2008.)

child.pub-comments: Related to Nepalese Sign Language; may be the same language as Indian Sign Language. Used in urban centers with some regional variation in vocabulary.
child.publications: Gordon, Raymond G. (ed.). 2005. Ethnologue: Languages of the World, 15 edn. http://www.ethnologue.com/15/web.asp. (09 July, 2008.)
Gordon, Raymond G. (ed.). 2005. Ethnologue: Languages of the World, 15 edn. http://www.ethnologue.com/15/web.asp. (09 July, 2008.)

child.pub-comments: Related to Taiwanese and Korean sign languages. 'Temane' is the former name.
child.publications: Gordon, Raymond G. (ed.). 2005. Ethnologue: Languages of the World, 15 edn. http://www.ethnologue.com/15/web.asp. (09 July, 2008.)
Gordon, Raymond G. (ed.). 2005. Ethnologue: Languages of the World, 15 edn. http://www.ethnologue.com/15/web.asp. (09 July, 2008.)
Gordon, Raymond G. (ed.). 2005. Ethnologue: Languages of the World, 15 edn. http://www.ethnologue.com/15/web.asp. (09 July, 2008.)
Gordon, Raymond G. (ed.). 2005. Ethnologue: Languages of the World, 15 edn. http://www.ethnologue.com/15/web.asp. (09 July, 2008.)
Gordon, Raymond G. (ed.). 2005. Ethnologue: Languages of the World, 15 edn. http://www.ethnologue.com/15/web.asp. (09 July, 2008.)

child.pub-comments: There are several dialects, of which Shanghai is the most influential. Few signs of foreign origin. The varieties used in Hong Kong, Taiwan, and Malaysia may have changed. Developed since the late 1950s. There are also Chinese character signs. Not influenced by American Sign Language.
child.publications: Gordon, Raymond G. (ed.). 2005. Ethnologue: Languages of the World, 15 edn. http://www.ethnologue.com/15/web.asp. (09 July, 2008.)
child.geography: China. Also used in Malaysia, Taiwan.

child.pub-comments: Not related to the original sign languages of Thailand, but there is some similarity.
child.publications: Gordon, Raymond G. (ed.). 2005. Ethnologue: Languages of the World, 15 edn. http://www.ethnologue.com/15/web.asp. (09 July, 2008.)

child.pub-comments: Related to Japanese and Taiwanese sign languages. There is a manual system for spelling.
child.publications: Gordon, Raymond G. (ed.). 2005. Ethnologue: Languages of the World, 15 edn. http://www.ethnologue.com/15/web.asp. (09 July, 2008.)

child.pub-comments: It uses a combination of indigenous signs and American Sign Language. Before 1950 Chiangmai and Bangkok had their own separate but related sign languages, and probably other 'urban' areas had their own sign languages, related to present sign languages in parts of Laos and Viet Nam, including Haiphong. The signs used at the deaf school at Tak are reported to be very different. There is a manual system for spelling.
child.publications: Gordon, Raymond G. (ed.). 2005. Ethnologue: Languages of the World, 15 edn. http://www.ethnologue.com/15/web.asp. (09 July, 2008.)
child.geography: Thailand, major regional centers and Bangkok.

child.pub-comments: Not derived from and relatively little influence from other sign languages. No special signs have been introduced from outside by educators. Minor dialect variation. The sign language used in classrooms and that by deaf adults outside is different. The first deaf school was established in Jerusalem in 1934. A fingerspelling system was developed in 1976.
child.publications: Gordon, Raymond G. (ed.). 2005. Ethnologue: Languages of the World, 15 edn. http://www.ethnologue.com/15/web.asp. (09 July, 2008.)

child.pub-comments: Related to sign languages in Viet Nam and earlier ones in Thailand. May be more than one sign language.
child.publications: Gordon, Raymond G. (ed.). 2005. Ethnologue: Languages of the World, 15 edn. http://www.ethnologue.com/15/web.asp. (09 July, 2008.)

child.pub-comments: Apparently distinct from Israeli Sign Language.
child.publications: Gordon, Raymond G. (ed.). 2005. Ethnologue: Languages of the World, 15 edn. http://www.ethnologue.com/15/web.asp. (09 July, 2008.)

child.pub-comments: Related to present sign languages in Laos and Viet Nam (Haiphong, Hanoi, Ho Chi Minh City). A distinct language from Thai Sign Language.
child.publications: Gordon, Raymond G. (ed.). 2005. Ethnologue: Languages of the World, 15 edn. http://www.ethnologue.com/15/web.asp. (09 July, 2008.)

child.pub-comments: Related to sign languages in Haiphong, Ho Chi Minh City, Laos, and earlier sign languages in Thailand.
child.publications: Gordon, Raymond G. (ed.). 2005. Ethnologue: Languages of the World, 15 edn. http://www.ethnologue.com/15/web.asp. (09 July, 2008.)
Gordon, Raymond G. (ed.). 2005. Ethnologue: Languages of the World, 15 edn. http://www.ethnologue.com/15/web.asp. (09 July, 2008.)

child.pub-comments: Several sign languages used by different schools. British English fingerspelling also used.
child.publications: Gordon, Raymond G. (ed.). 2005. Ethnologue: Languages of the World, 15 edn. http://www.ethnologue.com/15/web.asp. (09 July, 2008.)
